title: Cardiac Physiology and Disease Susceptibility
content: Discusses cardiac physiology and what makes the human heart susceptible to disease. Provides evidence for what supports his approach to exercise–elucidating both positive and negative kinds of exercise for heart health.

title: Role of Nutrition in Heart Health
content: Discusses the role of nutrition, specific nutrients, and pharmacological interventions to support heart and brain longevity.

title: Understanding Atherosclerosis
content: Understanding atherosclerosis and the misconception that it’s a “plumbing problem”.

title: The Danger in Excessive Exercise
content: The danger in excessive exercise—a reverse J-shaped mortality curve.

title: Exercise for Longevity
content: The best kinds of exercise for longevity—The Copenhagen City Heart Study. Being a more balanced athlete and finding the right exercise intensity.

title: Heart Rate Metrics
content: Heart rate during exercise, resting heart rate, and other important metrics.

title: Nutrition for Cardiovascular Health
content: Nutrition for cardiovascular health. Important nutrients: Magnesium, potassium, calcium, sodium, and collagen.

title: Pharmacological Interventions for Heart Health
content: SGLT2 inhibition for diabetes, cardio-protection, and general longevity. GLP-1 agonists for weight loss and reducing cardiovascular risk. Statins—mechanism of action, safety, and useful alternatives.

title: Cardiovascular Risk and Arterial Calcification
content: A 40-year view on cardiovascular risk, and the possibility of reversing arterial calcification.

title: Nutrients for Cardiovascular Disease Risk Reduction
content: Evidence for high dose EPA and DHA for the reduction of cardiovascular disease risk.

title: Impact of Nutrients on Mental Health
content: The impact of omega-3, curcumin, and other compounds on mental health and dementia.

title: Training Principles for Longevity
content: Training principles for longevity

title: Preventing Cardiovascular Disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more

title: Pros and Cons of GLP-1 Weight Loss Drugs and Metformin
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent

title: Overcoming Trauma and Living a Meaningful Life
content: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life

title: Cell Therapy and Gene Therapy
content: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more

title: Alzheimer's Disease and Lifestyle Factors
content: Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more

title: Cancer Risk and Lifestyle Factors
content: Cancer risk including the relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer

title: Exercise and Protein Consumption
content: New focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding

title: Understanding Atherosclerosis
content: Understanding atherosclerosis and the misconception that it’s a 'plumbing problem'

title: Coronary Arterial Calcification
content: Assessment of coronary arterial calcification using an inexpensive and low-radiation CT scan called CardioScan to measure coronary arterial calcification

title: Acne Scars and Prevention
content: We can’t make the acne scars go away. They’re there forever once you have those calcium deposits. But we can pretty much make the risk go away. That’s why prevention is just so effective and so instrumental.

title: Exercise and Health
content: If exercise were a drug, it would be the best drug we have for preventing heart disease, dementia, osteoporosis, depression, diabetes, and obesity. But like any drug, the dose must be appropriate. For decrease of serious cardiovascular disease, benefit of exercise starts at just 15 minutes of brisk walking per day and increases with an increasing amount of exercise. At the most extreme doses of exercise, however, some of the benefit is lost.

title: Heart Function and Exercise
content: The heart is only about the size of a fist, but continuously pumps about 5 liters of blood throughout the body per minute, amounting to three to four billion beats throughout a lifetime. During intense activity, the hearts of some athletes pump as much as 30-35 liters of blood per minute. Professional cyclists and cross country skiers get as high as 40 liters per minute. In a well trained athlete, intense exercise will increase heart rate by about three-fold, say 45 to 170 bpm for example. The volume of blood being pumped, however, increases by about six-fold (5 to 30+ liters per minute). Increased cardiac output, or the volume of blood pumped per beat, explains this discrepancy. For cardiac output to increase, the internal volume of the heart must also increase. With extreme amounts of exercise, this stretching of the heart can be problematic.

title: Oxidative Stress of Exercise
content: In addition, exercise creates oxidative stress. After about 45 to 50 minutes of high-intensity exercise, the body’s antioxidant capacity to resolve the oxidative stress is exhausted and endothelial function is negatively affected at this point. This coincides with increased blood levels of troponins and the N-terminal prohormone of brain natriuretic peptide (NT pro-BNP), which are both markers of heart damage.

title: Exercise and Aging
content: Especially after age 40 or 45, really protracted exercise will cause those small little micro damage, like overstretching and tearing. This happens because the high levels of catecholamines and free radicals that are now unbuffered.

title: Longevity versus Performance
content: In short, longevity and performance are different goals. In regard to health, if you want to run a marathon or do something similar for the sake of accomplishment, that is fine, but it should not become a regular habit.

title: Exercise and Heart Rhythm
content: Premature ventricular contractions can be caused by the high levels of catecholamines and oxidative stress produced during prolonged intense exercise, resulting in fibrosis and scar tissue that can disrupt heart rhythm and facilitate development of atrial fibrillation.

title: Excessive Exercise and Longevity
content: A Harvard study showed that the people who exercised the most lost 38% of the longevity benefit compared to those who exercised more moderately. Further demonstrating the concerns of excessive exercise, professional cyclists have been shown to be more likely to develop atrial fibrillation.

title: Best Kinds of Exercise for Longevity
content: Nearly 10,000 Danes were followed for more than 20 years. Participants were grouped based on type of physical activity, including running, cycling, swimming, “health club activities” (i.e., exercising at a gym), tennis, badminton, and soccer. Tennis, badminton, and soccer were associated with the greatest longevity benefit, followed by running, cycling, calisthenics, and swimming.

title: Balanced Exercise and Intensity
content: High volumes of really high intensity exercise is just not the ideal approach to fitness. After 30 or 45 minutes of aerobic exercise, if you want to do more circle back home and do some yoga, do some weights, these things that don’t necessarily tax your heart the same way that the other high intensity sports do.

title: Heart Rate and Exercise
content: The most important parameters about pulse are: Resting HR—We want to get that nice and low. Heart rate variability—we want that to be more variable when you take slow deep breaths. This is why meditation or yoga is a really good thing to add to somebody’s fitness regimen.

title: Resting Heart Rate and Health
content: A lower resting heart rate is associated with increased longevity. Later in life, sick sinus syndrome can lower heart rate. Alcohol consumption, stress, and inadequate sleep can all increase resting heart rate.

title: Nutrition for Cardiovascular Health
content: A Meditteranean diet emphasizing fish and minimization of refined carbohydrates, combined with intermittent fasting, is the best dietary approach for cardiovascular health. This dietary approach is also beneficial for preventing diabetes, dementia, obesity, and other common chronic diseases.

title: Olive Oil and Health
content: The benefits of olive oil depend on it being extra virgin and having high polyphenol content. This type of olive oil should give a sensation at the back of the throat similar to black pepper.

title: Olive Oil and Saturated Fat
content: Consumers need to be aware – sometimes even products labeled as extra virgin olive oil are really nothing more than canola oil with some olive oil mixed in. The epidemiology is confounded by people who consume more saturated fat typically also consuming unhealthy ingredients like refined carbohydrates. A moderate amount of saturated fat is part of our evolutionary history, but that an excessive amount is not a good idea. Sugar and other refined carbohydrates are a much greater concern.

title: Important Nutrients: Magnesium, Potassium, Calcium, Sodium, and Collagen
content: Magnesium and Potassium are important cofactors for many reactions in the body. Nuts are a good source of magnesium. Eating “nose to tail” includes cooking bone, which provides calcium hydroxyapatite. Standard calcium supplements are in the form of calcium carbonate and calcium gluconate. Collagen is beneficial for hair, skin, nails, and bones; and it is even beneficial for building and maintaining muscle mass. Sodium intake needs to be careful for people with heart failure and kidney disease.

title: SGLT2 Inhibition for Diabetes, Cardio-protection, and General Longevity
content: SGLT2 inhibitors are a class of drugs that blocks sodium glucose co-transporter 2 in the tubule of kidney cells. This basically blocks reabsorption of glucose, resulting in increased excretion of glucose through the urine. For this reason, SGLT2 inhibitors are used to treat diabetes. EMPA-REG, the first large clinical trial on an SGLT2 inhibitor, showed a decrease in heart failure hospitalizations and cardiovascular deaths in type 2 diabetics.

title: GLP-1 Agonists for Weight Loss and Reducing Cardiovascular Risk
content: GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) is a hormone that promotes insulin secretion and tends to decline in type 2 diabetics. GLP-1 agonists lower fasting insulin and increase postprandial insulin. GLP-1 agonists are great for weight loss.

title: Statins—Mechanism of Action, Safety, and Useful Alternatives
content: Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis, their benefit is more likely a result of increasing the LCL receptor in the liver. Despite the large amount of evidence on efficacy of statins, there are concerns about their use. Loss of coenzyme Q10 and associated muscle pain are legitimate concerns, they can be easily resolved through supplementation.

title: A 40-year View on Cardiovascular Risk, and the Possibility of Reversing Arterial Calcification
content: If someone has a low 10-year risk calculation but has high ApoB, current recommendations are to do nothing beyond lifestyle modifications. Based on the work of Allan Sniderman, it is more important to look at 30- or 40- year risk.

title: Evidence for High Dose EPA and DHA for the Reduction of Cardiovascular Disease Risk
content: The REDUCE-IT trial showed 4 g/d of a purified form of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) to decrease cardiovascular deaths and events in people with cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or risk factors including high triglycerides by 20%. Another recent trial, the EVAPORATE study, showed 4 g/d of the same purified form of EPA to decrease coronary plaque by 17%.

title: The Impact of Omega-3, Curcumin, and Other Compounds on Mental Health and Dementia
content: Omega-3 supplementation is cheap and safe, with profound benefits that can help keep people off of antidepressant medications. Highly-absorbable curcumin (Theracurmin) for preventing Alzheimer’s disease. There is observational data on millions of people suggesting that TNF-α inhibition decreases Alzheimer’s risk by 60-70%.

title: Omega-3 Deficiency and Mental Health
content: Upwards of like 90% of Americans aren’t getting enough omega-3 in their diet and it correlates with depression, ADHD, suicide, cognition, dementia, all those things … this is like a super easy way to markedly improve mental health.

title: Preventive Medicine and Lifestyle
content: For people aspiring to be medical professionals who focus on prevention, it does not have to be all or nothing – you can be involved in the more standard and reactive aspects of medicine, such as angioplasty and lipid lowering, but you can limit this to just a portion of your focus. Prevention will become a more important part of medicine as more people realize the payoff in regard to getting more out of life.

title: Lifestyle and Health
content: … this whole world is set up to minimize activity and maximize calorie consumption, but there’s also people who are paying close attention and we have all of these powerful tools and use this information to help each other and to live not only longer, but more sort of active and fulfilling and enjoyable lives.
